title: Wednesday, 17th January, 2018

11:03 am

Informa PLC (INF:LSE): Last: 673.60, down 73.8 (-9.87%), High: 721.00, Low: 670.00, Volume: 9.21m
red needs to raide 4 times mkt cap. yep we know how that one ends up.

Informa shareholders really don't fancy this.

KS11:19am

(@chevelle i think they mostly just run conferences, some 300 of them)

Chevelle I didn't know Informa ran the Monaco Yacht Show
11:19 am
BE11:20am

And both companies are carrying quite a bit of debt in what is a fairly cyclical industry, so the "stronger together" theme is likely to be a hard sell.

BE11:20am

So far, we have very little detail.

BE11:20am

Here's Exane:

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Overall, we expect the deal to prove EPS accretive for Informa shareholders even at high levels of equity financing and at a material premium to the UBM undisturbed share price, especially with synergies. The ROIC of the deal is solid, if unspectacular. The portion of cash vs shares will depend on the premium and willingness of Informa to raise debt beyond its preferred maximum level at c2.5-3.0x net debt/EBITDA.

Chevelle I am still lolling at Euromoney getting dawn raided over paper market price...things....
Blank canvas morning
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Ship's company!
BE11:21am

We have been historically sceptical of major cost synergies from events portfolio combinations. [A review of] the cost base of a typical exhibition and benchmark recent deals [finds] cost synergies in the region of GBP20m-50m as credible, especially with UBM central costs at cGBP25m. Tax synergies are a source of further upside risk.

BE11:22am

And Citi:

Boncoeur @Fletcher: are you Capt Mainwaring in disguise?
11:22 am
BE11:23am

From an Informa standpoint, we think the deal makes strategic sense for a number of reasons: 1) it increases the group’s exposure to Events (from roughly 1/3 of revenues to 2/3), 2) on the back of that, we should see better group organic growth and margins, 3) margins should be further boosted by cost synergies,

BE11:23am

.... 4) we could even potentially see revenue synergies given the limited overlap in the respective groups’ events portfolios and 5) there may be a tax benefit given UBM’s tax losses (Informa’s P&L tax rate is c. 22% vs UBM’s at less than 17%). It is worth remembering that leverage of the combined group should increase from c. 2x Net Debt/EBITDA to closer to 3x.

BE11:23am

And questions on timing ......

11:23 am
BE11:24am

. While the statement from Informa calls out
the benefits of the rest of the group, one of our concerns (and the basis of our relative preference for UBM vs Informa) has been around business mix and exposure to areas such as Knowledge & Networking and Academic Publishing. Does this deal signal that Informa management too have some concerns around the longer-term growth potential of these non-Events businesses and therefore feel under pressure to buy into areas of higher growth in order to sustain momentum going forward? Could this be the start of further portfolio rationalisation, with Informa trying to morph itself into more of a pure-play Events business? In the short term, we suspect not, but we do find the marked change in strategy interesting.

KS11:25am

Is the underlying strategic thought process here that publishing is An Awful Business To Be In and so anything that makes publishing a smaller part of your company is Good?

KS11:25am

(Speaking as someone in the publishing business)

Tom Dalgleish @Fletch, beached whale by name of Donald Trump to starboard
RA catching up made me chuckle
RA may I have thoughts on this budget carry on in the US?
11:26 am
BE11:26am

That's part of the argument, undeniably. Plus the argument that events are cash cows when you do them right.

KS11:26am

You know, that's got me thinking... maybe FT Alphaville should do an event?

KS11:26am

In the summer or something...

RA I was thinking yesterday @KS that some beers are needed
11:26 am
BE11:27am

Cripes! You should pitch that kind of blue-sky thinking to management.

BE11:27am

Anyway, the "do them right" caveat here is important.

BE11:27am

Which is something Berenberg picks up on .....

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Informa management recently mentioned the potential issues it sees in UBM’s portfolio and
indicated that there had been specific reasons why it had chosen not to go for some of the
assets that UBM has acquired in recent years (eg the Advanstar fashion exhibitions, Allworld). Hence, paying a premium for UBM overall to acquire such assets, when Informa declined to pay what UBM did in the first place, seems hard to justify.

Soundbuy ITE Grp - thought that would have been more of a target....

They really don't like this idea.

KS11:28am

(@RA Sadly for my health, I never say no to beers, so drop me an email)

11:28 am
BE11:28am

More practically, UBM’s leverage is not particularly low (it is only just delevering into its
target range by end-2017), and nor is Informa particularly underlevered at 2.3x net debt/EBITDA at end-2017 (with a target range of 2.0-2.5x). Therefore, significant equity issuance would probably be needed: at current share prices, UBM is trading at 17x 2018E earnings with Informa at 15.5x: hence, Informa would be issuing equity at a lower multiple to pay a higher one.

Alchemy30 @red could you give ft link regarding the bond, thanks
BE11:28am

I mean, really really don't like it.

BE11:29am

Are the returns that attractive? We would argue not. At the current share price, the deal would give UBM an EV of c£3.7bn, or 12.5x 2019E EBITA (versus INF at 12x). Yes, it could remove UBM central costs of c£25m, but overt short-term synergies outside this are not huge. At this price (with no other premium), we estimate Informa would make only a 7.1% ROIC in 2019E (even in a stronger biennial year for UBM) after the removal of UBM central costs (even assuming UBM’s lower tax rate, before we see the impact of US tax reform).

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Berenberg also highlights that the 2008 proposal fell apart because there were no major synergies apart from central costs .....

alewis2005 @KS does *any* journalist ever say no to beers?

11:33 am
KS11:33am

Bloomberg story on the tape this morning saying Brookfield and Onex planning an offer of around 300p a share.

Groundhog Day Going to repeat my question from before then for IWG: I am wondering if the BBG story does not imply that Mark Dixon already said he is open to it. Otherwise why "firm" offer?
Groundhog Day thanks
BE11:34am

(Or was it overnight? Whatever.) ... This is, I think, a fleshed out version of the rumour we nudged at in Friday's paper: https://www.ft.com...-88f7-5465a6ce1a00

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Well ..... @Groundhog notes in the BBG story a hint that Mark Dixon is open to the offer, and it's other board members that are pushing for a higher price.

BE11:38am

That would be opposite to what we'd been hearing earlier in the month, and might also suggest the bidding process has been more incremental in terms of the back and forth.

Groundhog Day Thanks for picking it up - note my conjecture that Mark Dixon is open to it is solely from the fact that BBG uses the term "firm" in the offer. Any I am saying why would you prepare a firm offer if you did not know the 25% holder was on board?
BE11:39am

Is that infuriatingly vague or just vague enough? Oh, who cares, have some Peel Hunt.

Lemmy Groundhog: firm is a defined term under the takeover code, it's a formal bid
Groundhog Day @Lemmy: exactly
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Boncoeur @Tom Dalgleish. No, LOL & LOL
red for context retaiul sales dec 16 fell sharply so u will see a rise in dec 17 more than likely. mkt can explain away a fall in sterling given precisely that.
Lemmy (just saw your comment 1239 comment as I hit submit)
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Brookfield/Onex have a few days left to formalise an offer if one is to be made, and 300p is now mentioned in the press as the price (up from 260p). This would be undemanding – it doesn’t take much change in base assumptions to get there. Much depends on the facts behind the speculation, Mark Dixon’s attitude and the state of counter-bids, but we see 320-340p as justified.

BE11:40am

It does not take much to get fair value up from our 240p to 300p. Simply applying a WACC of 8% would do it. Or keep 10% but allow for ten years of growth not five as we currently use. Or give no value to growth at all, and apply a PER of 17x to mature EPS, which is what the December 2016 estate would deliver we estimate. None of this seems very demanding, and all of it still assumes that future margins are much lower than they have been in the recent past to reflect more aggressive competition. But many in the industry question the sustainability of WeWork’s prices, given its high costs, hence in 2-3 years the competitive environment may have, at least partially, reverted.
300p also excludes any acquisition and strategic synergies, which could be substantial. We note that RDI’s purchase of OSIT, announced earlier this week, cited synergies between ownership and the leased model for flexible space.

KS11:42am

That's an interesting argument from Peel Hunt. The company's worth more because it's main competitor is going to implode over the next 36 months. Not necessarily a bad one, but definitely an interesting one

11:42 am
KS11:42am

*its

BE11:43am

Indeed. A bet on IWG is probably a bet on WeWork failing.

Groundhog Day @BE, can you say, from what you have heard, whether Dixon seems open to 300GBp or would you have thought he is not impressed by that number
BE11:43am

Or, at least, not reinventing the industry by making it all unprofitable.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Oh, and @Groundhog, just to footnote:

BE11:44am

If you spin back to what we reported way back in June ..... https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-06-08/ ... the implication then was that Dixon was a willing seller and there was an auction process going on.

BE11:44am

Which we wrecked by reporting it.

Groundhog Day Thanks for the comments. Thing is back then it traded >340
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Now, at a rather lower price, the feel around the situation seems to be that Dixon remains a willing seller. But while he's founder and main shareholder, he doesn't command the board to ignore the interests of other shareholders if said board think they can extract a better price.

undefined
BE11:46am

And finally, on bids, quick mention of GKN.

11:46 am
GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 443.40, up 1.4 (+0.32%), High: 449.40, Low: 438.90, Volume: 13.80m
Groundhog Day Thanks again. I have a hard time seeing the other board members rejecting a 50% premium regardless of how bombed out the stock might have been...
BE11:47am

Melrose goes properly hostile rather than bear-hug hostile.

Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 231.80, down 2.5 (-1.07%), High: 236.00, Low: 227.20, Volume: 15.34m
11:47 am
BE11:47am

And GKN tells them to get stuffed, unsurprisingly.

Waterloo Anyone any insight into Boost VILX. Supposed to be 2.5x VIX but doesn't seem to work that way. VIX up 15% last night, VILX up 2% so not even tracking VIX let alone 2.5X.
BE11:49am

Note, revised offer only reflects Melrose's share price move. 81p and 1.49 Melrose shares is the same as the initial proposal.

BE11:50am

We also had the pension fund trustees weighing in yesterday, a theme we'd picked up earlier in the week. To save ourselves repeating, here's Citi on that.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

GKN’s pension trustees noted on Tuesday
that adjusted for the lump sum contribution of £250m paid in October, the UK scheme had an aggregate deficit of £1.1bn on a “gilts flat” basis (the theoretical deficit assuming 100% of assets in UK Gilts) or £1.9bn on a “solvency basis” which assumes the cost of a pension buyout; on this basis the Implied pension buyout cost of £0.8bn is at the upper end of the £0.2-0.8bn that we had estimated in our note from 16th Jan, but the “GKN guarantee” also looks to worth several hundred million. We estimate that the current funding deficit of the UK scheme is around ~£0.4bn following the £250m injection, but this inherently assumes the guarantee of GKN; the trustees comment that “any material change to the corporate and capital structure of GKN would lead the Trustees to reassess the strength of covenant going forward and determine appropriate funding plans based on that covenant and its associated level of risk”, implying that this funding deficit is only a valid figure of GKN “as is”.

BE11:51am

The trustees comment that the IAS19 deficit of £0.8bn in October is in-
line with expectations (of £1,063m as at July 2017, reduced by the £250m October
payment). Melrose’s statement from this morning “notes the statement” by the
trustees and comments that the numbers published are “entirely in line” with
Melrose’s own reading, but we’d point to our note of January 16th [...] showing that any “full breakup” needs to account for a significant pension injection, in our view. Melrose has confirmed this morning that it expects to sell the Power Metallurgy business (11% sales) in the medium term as well as “certain smaller businesses” in the other divisions, but does not advocate a full split of Aerospace and Driveline.

Tom Dalgleish We do pensions/superannuation much better than UK
KS11:52am

What kind of injection are people talking about if there's a takeover?

11:52 am
BE11:52am

I've seen figures around the £400m mark.

BE11:53am

The main point here, though, is that splitting aerospace and driveline looks very expensive indeed, for the reasons we detailed on Monday.

Soundbuy RPC off 5%, rough day yesterday too......another Bearfest?
BE11:53am

Which I think is why we have GKN saying "we'll kinda look at breaking up the business, sometime, whenever, promise"

11:53 am
BE11:54am

And you have Melrose saying, "we won't be as hasty as those GKN folks"

BE11:54am

To repeat myself once more: the breakup bid for GKN has had the odd effect of making a GKN breakup look less likely.

undefined

11:56 am
RPC Group PLC (RPC:LSE): Last: 763.60, down 35 (-4.38%), High: 797.00, Low: 753.40, Volume: 2.19m
Soundbuy .....ah.......missed that.......cheers
red provident taking a further lashing today. this one looks a whisker away from real trouble as well.
rwl DRX?
BE11:57am

When we initiated on RPC in November 2016, the investment thesis was simple and similar to several other stocks in our coverage: identify a niche industry where few existing operators have significant scale; gain scale through acquisition; then through that scale generate procurement advantages and manufacturing efficiencies that allow synergies to be created. As those synergies compound onto the larger profit base, use the resultant cash generation to acquire again. Initially the thesis worked well, but the rights issue and acquisition of Letica at the start of 2017 changed the debate. There were now accusations that RPC’s acquisitions were not creating value; that the exceptionals were too high and the resultant cash flow too low. We stuck with RPC throughout 2017 and saw the recovery from lows of c700p back to c900p. However, as we reassess our stock picks for the start of 2018, the combination of low growth and an uncertain return to acquisitions leads us to downgrade to Hold. We prefer DS Smith in the packaging space.

BE11:57am

I think that was around yesterday, but I've seen no better reason for RPC being hit this morning.
